title-group.article-title: Radiological and statistical analysis of impacted maxillary third molars in Korean adults

article-meta.aff: Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, College of Dentistry, Dankook University, Cheonan, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Chul-Hwan Kim, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, College of Dentistry, Dankook University, 119 Dandae-ro, Dongnam-gu, Cheonan 31116, Korea, TEL: +82-41-550-1996, E-mail: kimchoms@gmail.com, ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5199-2420

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: This study aimed to investigate the distribution of Archer’s Classification in impacted maxillary third molars in Korean adults, evaluate the effect of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar on the position and angulation of the impacted maxillary third molar, and analyze the relationship between root involvement with the maxillary sinus.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images of 384 impacted maxillary third molars from 277 patients who visited Dankook University Dental Hospital between March 2021 and February 2024 were analyzed. The teeth were classified according to Archer’s Classification (depth and axis), and the long axis angles of the maxillary first, second, and third molars as well as root involvement with the maxillary sinus were measured. Statistical analyses were conducted using the Mann–Whitney U test, chi-square test, and logistic regression analysis, with a significance level set at 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Depth categories B and C, and axis categories mesial and vertical were the most prevalent, with no significant differences in distribution based on sex (P>0.05). A significant negative correlation was found, indicating that as the buccal inclination of the maxillary second molar increased, the impacted maxillary third molar tended to incline more palatally (Kendall’s tau-b=–0.245, Spearman’s rho=–0.353, P<0.001). Root involvement with the maxillary sinus was not significantly associated with depth in Archer’s Classification but showed a statistically significant difference based on axis (P=0.002).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study systematically evaluated the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars through Archer’s Classification and CBCT analysis, providing a clinical predictive index for assessing extraction difficulty and determining the surgical approach. In particular, the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar was identified as an important factor in predicting the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: The impacted maxillary third molar is a common clinical concern encountered by oral and maxillofacial surgeons, primarily resulting from a lack of eruption space or an abnormal tooth position1,2. The extraction of these teeth poses significant surgical challenges due to the limited operative field caused by adjacent teeth and their proximity to the maxillary sinus, leading to an increased risk of complications3,4. Notably, the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars are recognized as key factors influencing extraction difficulty and the likelihood of postoperative complications5.

Previous studies have categorized the position of impacted maxillary third molars based on depth and axis3,6, as proposed by Archer7, and cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) has emerged as a valuable tool in providing additional diagnostic information that is often difficult to obtain with panoramic radiographs2,8. However, studies analyzing extraction difficulty using these classification criteria and radiographic assessments remain relatively scarce.

Existing research on the difficulty and complications of impacted third molar extraction has predominantly focused on the mandibular third molars9. In contrast, studies investigating the positional and angular characteristics of impacted maxillary third molars, particularly the influence of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar, are limited.

In cases where impacted maxillary third molars exhibit a palatal inclination, the conventional buccal approach may pose challenges in securing an adequate surgical field, thereby complicating the extraction process. In such instances, a palatal approach has been suggested as a viable alternative5. However, studies providing clear predictive indicators for selecting an appropriate approach are limited. Therefore, further research is necessary to facilitate preoperative prediction of extraction difficulty and to establish optimal surgical strategies.

This study aims to investigate the distribution of Archer’s Classification6 in Korean adults, analyze the impact of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar on the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars, and evaluate the relationship between root proximity to the maxillary sinus. To achieve this, CBCT images were utilized to classify impacted maxillary third molars according to Archer’s Classification6, measure the buccopalatal angulation, and assess root involvement with the maxillary sinus. The findings of this study seek to provide a clinical predictive index for impacted maxillary third molar extractions and establish fundamental data for evaluating extraction difficulty.

sec.title: 1. Study subjects
sec.p: This study included patients diagnosed with impacted maxillary third molars at Dankook University Dental Hospital between March 2021 and February 2024. The exclusion criteria were as follows: patients under 18 years of age, those with a history of orthodontic treatment, patients without CBCT imaging, individuals with missing maxillary first or second molars, and those who had received prosthetic treatment on the maxillary first or second molars. A total of 384 teeth from 277 patients were analyzed.

sec.title: 2. Study methods
sec.p: Panoramic radiographs and CBCT (RCT800-SC; Raydent) were used to classify impacted maxillary third molars according to Archer’s Classification.(Table 1) The long axis angles of the maxillary first, second, and third molars relative to the midsagittal plane were measured.(Fig. 1) The midsagittal plane was defined on the coronal view of CBCT images as a vertical reference line manually drown along the nasal septum and vomer. Root involvement with the maxillary sinus was assessed based on the spatial relationship observed on CBCT images. When a distinct cortical bone boundary was clearly present between the root apices and the sinus floor, the tooth was classified as having no root involvement. In contrast, cases where the cortical bone was absent, indistinct, or where the root apices were overlapping or contacting the sinus floor were classified as root involvement. Angles were recorded as positive (+) when inclined buccally and negative (–) when inclined palatally. To evaluate the potential influence of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar on the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars, the study population was divided into two groups based on the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar relative to the first molar. Group B included cases where the maxillary second molar exhibited a greater buccal inclination than the maxillary first molar, whereas Group N included cases where the second molar was either normally aligned or inclined palatally relative to the first molar.

sec.title: 3. Statistical methods
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed using IBM SPSS Statistics (ver. 30.0; IBM). The Mann–Whitney U test, chi-square test, and logistic regression analysis were employed for statistical evaluation. The significance level was set at a P-value of less than 0.05.
This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Dankook University Dental Hospital (IRB No. DKUDHIRB 2025-03-003).

sec.title: 1. Characteristics of study subjects
sec.p: Among the total 277 patients and 384 teeth analyzed, 139 female patients (196 teeth) and 138 male patients (188 teeth) were included. The group in which the maxillary second molar was inclined buccally (hereafter, Group B) consisted of 192 teeth, while the group in which the second molar was either normally aligned or inclined palatally (hereafter, Group N) also comprised 192 teeth. The groups were formed by applying the classification criterion to the entire sample of impacted maxillary third molars collected during the study period. The equal distribution of teeth between the two groups occurred coincidentally and was not the result of intentional matching. The mean age of all subjects was 27.54 years, with Group B averaging 26.63 years and Group N averaging 28.45 years. The P-value was greater than 0.05, indicating no statistically significant difference. Regarding sex distribution (female:male), Group B had a ratio of 83:109, while Group N had 113:79, with a P-value of 0.002, indicating that males were significantly more prevalent in Group B, whereas females were significantly more prevalent in Group N.

sec.title: 2. Archer’s Classification
sec.p: The distribution of Archer’s Classification based on sex showed no statistically significant differences in either depth or axis (P=0.440, P=0.538). However, a statistically significant association between depth and axis was found in the overall population as well as in sex-based subgroups, as determined by the chi-square test (P<0.001).(Table 2) In the overall population as well as in the male and female subgroups, depth categories B and C, as well as axis categories vertical and mesial, were predominant. When categorized by depth and axis in the overall population, the most common classifications were C-mesial, B-vertical, C-vertical, and B-mesial & C-buccal. In males, the highest frequencies were observed in C-mesial, B-vertical & C-buccal, and B-buccal & C-vertical, whereas in females, the order was C-mesial, B-mesial, B-vertical, and C-vertical. Across all groups, teeth with Depth C and a mesial axis were the most prevalent. There was no statistically significant difference in depth distribution between Group B and Group N (P=0.498).(Table 3) However, the distribution of axis differed between the two groups: Group B exhibited a higher prevalence of mesial inclination, while Group N demonstrated higher distributions in buccal and distal inclinations (P<0.001).(Table 4)

sec.title: 3. Angulation of the maxillary third molar
sec.p: There was no statistically significant difference in the angulation of the maxillary third molar between males and females (P=0.326). When comparing the second molar groups, the mean angulation in Group B was –3.75±11.16°, with a median of –5.25° (interquartile range [IQR]: –17.78° to 9.45°), whereas in Group N, the mean was 24.71±27.74°, with a median of 5.8° (IQR: –5.53° to 28.7°). The P-value was less than 0.001, indicating that the maxillary third molar was significantly more palatally inclined in Group B than in Group N.(Table 5) The buccopalatal angle of the maxillary second molar was also measured. In Group B, the mean angle of the maxillary second molar was 17.65±6.29°, with a median of 16.1° (IQR: 12.6° to 20.92°). In Group N, the mean angle was –3.75±24.78°, with a median of –5.25° (IQR: –17.78° to 9.45°). These results reflect the group classification criterion and confirm the difference in second molar inclination between the groups. This trend was further supported by the linear correlation analysis between the buccopalatal angle of the maxillary second molar and the buccopalatal angle of the impacted maxillary third molar. The Kendall’s tau-b coefficient was –0.245, and the Spearman’s rho coefficient was –0.353, both with P-values below 0.001, demonstrating a statistically significant negative correlation—meaning that as the buccal inclination of the maxillary second molar increased, the maxillary third molar tended to incline more palatally.(Fig. 2)

sec.title: 4. Root involvement with the maxillary sinus
sec.p: There was no statistically significant difference in root involvement with the maxillary sinus based on sex (P=0.611). Regarding the second molar (absence:presence of sinus involvement), Group B showed a distribution of 97:95, while Group N had 94:98, with a P-value of 0.759, indicating no statistical significance.(Table 6) Additionally, no statistically significant association was found between root involvement with the maxillary sinus and the buccopalatal angulation of the maxillary second molar (P=0.508) or the buccopalatal angulation of the maxillary third molar (P=0.526). The association between root involvement with the maxillary sinus and depth in Archer’s Classification was also not statistically significant (P=0.066).(Table 7) However, in terms of axis, cases with mesial inclination were less likely to have root involvement with the maxillary sinus (87:52), while distal and vertical inclinations showed a higher prevalence of sinus involvement (3:7 and 36:64, respectively). This difference was statistically significant (P=0.002).(Table 8)

sec.title: IV. Discussion
sec.p: This study investigated the distribution of Archer’s Classification in Korean adults with impacted maxillary third molars, analyzed the effect of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar on the position and angulation of impacted maxillary third molars, and evaluated the relationship between root involvement with the maxillary sinus. The results demonstrated that in both the overall population and sex-based subgroups, teeth classified as Depth C with a mesial axis were the most prevalent. Regarding the relationship with the second molar, it was observed that in Group B, where the second molar was inclined buccally, the impacted maxillary third molar tended to incline palatally, which was statistically significant (P<0.001). Additionally, a significant difference was noted in the distribution of axis across the groups (P<0.001), and axis classification was also correlated with root involvement in the maxillary sinus (P=0.002). In contrast, no significant association was found between tooth angulation and root involvement with the maxillary sinus. These findings suggest that the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar may serve as a crucial indicator for predicting extraction difficulty and determining the appropriate surgical approach for impacted maxillary third molars.

The distribution of Archer’s Classification showed no significant differences based on sex. The most common depth categories were B and C, whereas Depth A was the least prevalent due to the focus on impacted teeth. The most frequent axis types were mesial and vertical, with the most common depth-axis combination being Depth C with a mesial axis. Regarding the second molar, Group B exhibited a significantly higher prevalence of mesial axis, whereas Group N showed higher frequencies of buccal and distal axis inclinations. The predominance of the mesial axis in Group B aligns with the study by Sun et al.5, which suggested that a palatal approach is beneficial for mesioangular palatally impacted third molars. This positional characteristic may serve as a crucial criterion for selecting an appropriate extraction approach. Additionally, the higher prevalence of buccal and distal axis in Group N is consistent with the findings of Ye et al.4, who recommended a buccal approach. Conversely, no significant differences were observed in depth distribution between the groups, indicating that the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar does not influence the impaction depth of the maxillary third molar. These findings suggest that Archer’s Classification, particularly the axis category, may be helpful in anticipating potential extraction difficulty and in planning the surgical approach.

In Group B, where the maxillary second molar was inclined buccally, the impacted maxillary third molar showed a tendency to incline palatally, which was consistent with the negative correlations found in Kendall’s tau-b (–0.245) and Spearman’s rho (–0.353). This aligns with the study by Badawi Fayad et al.1, which identified a correlation between the eruption of maxillary third molars and the inclination of adjacent teeth. Furthermore, this study extends previous research by highlighting the influence of the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar on the positional changes of impacted maxillary third molars. These findings support the study by Sun et al.5, which advocated for the utility of a palatal approach and proposed the inclination of the second molar as a predictive indicator for determining the surgical approach.

This study also assessed the correlation between the angulations of the maxillary second and third molars and root involvement with the maxillary sinus, but no significant associations were found. Additionally, there was no significant correlation between the depth category of Archer’s Classification and root involvement with the maxillary sinus (P=0.066). These results contradict previous studies, such as Lim et al.3, which analyzed the relationship between tooth depth and postoperative maxillary sinus perforation, and Seo et al.8, which investigated the correlation between tooth depth and the incidence of postoperative maxillary sinusitis. However, the axis classification showed a significant relationship with root involvement in the maxillary sinus, with fewer cases of sinus involvement in the mesial axis group (87:52) and a higher prevalence in the distal and vertical axis groups (3:7, 36:64), with statistical significance (P=0.002). This finding contradicts the study by Hasegawa et al.6, which reported a higher incidence of maxillary sinus perforation in mesioangular impactions. However, the discrepancy may stem from the fact that this study focused on preoperative root involvement with the sinus, whereas previous studies examined postoperative maxillary sinus perforation. These findings suggest that CBCT-based assessment of root involvement in the maxillary sinus is not an absolute predictor of postoperative sinus perforation.

CBCT played a crucial role in this study, consistent with the findings of de Andrade et al.2 and Hermann et al.10, which reported that CBCT provides more precise information compared to conventional panoramic radiographs. In particular, CBCT is a valuable tool for accurately evaluating tooth position, angulation, and root involvement with the maxillary sinus, contributing to the preoperative assessment of extraction difficulty and the risk of complications.

In clinical practice, the extraction difficulty of impacted maxillary third molars is influenced by both impaction patterns and anatomical relationships. Palatal inclination of the third molar presents increased extraction difficulty due to limited access through the conventional buccal approach, thicker palatal cortical bone, and restricted visualization, which necessitates a more technically demanding surgical approach. Additionally, mesial inclination tends to complicate luxation and increases the risk of injury to the adjacent second molar, whereas distal inclination may be less challenging if anatomical space permits, though root proximity to the sinus may still present risks. Depth of impaction also plays a critical role; teeth classified as Depth C or D are generally more deeply embedded and require more extensive bone removal, increasing surgical difficulty and the potential for complications.

Furthermore, the relationship between the root apex and the maxillary sinus floor is a crucial factor influencing the risk of sinus perforation. Cases with absent cortical bone or direct root contact with the sinus floor exhibit a higher risk of membrane perforation during extraction. Therefore, preoperative CBCT evaluation of these anatomical factors is essential for surgical planning and risk mitigation.

This study has some limitations. As a retrospective study conducted at a single institution, it did not fully consider various anatomical factors beyond tooth angulation. Additionally, the lack of objective quantitative measures for extraction difficulty and the inability to directly assess the clinical relationship between tooth position and surgical difficulty are notable limitations. Future studies should include multi-center research with a broader patient population and incorporate direct clinical data on extraction difficulty and complication rates.

sec.title: V. Conclusion
sec.p: 1. Among the Archer’s Classification categories for impacted maxillary third molars in Korean adults, Depth C was the most prevalent, and mesial axis was the most frequently observed axis.
2. A tendency was observed where an increased buccal inclination of the maxillary second molar corresponded to a greater palatal inclination of the impacted maxillary third molar.

3. Teeth with a mesial axis were less likely to have roots involved in the maxillary sinus, whereas those with a distal or vertical axis had a higher likelihood of root involvement with the maxillary sinus.

This study confirmed the distribution of Archer’s Classification in Korean adults with impacted maxillary third molars and established that the buccopalatal inclination of the maxillary second molar significantly influences the position and angulation of the impacted maxillary third molar. These findings provide a clinical predictive index for assessing extraction difficulty and selecting the optimal surgical approach. Additionally, the distribution of axis in Archer’s Classification and CBCT-based analysis offer fundamental data for determining the extraction approach and contribute to preventing complications such as maxillary sinus perforation. These results present significant academic and clinical implications for the extraction of impacted maxillary third molars.

fn.p: J.Y.L. participated in data collection and writing the manuscript. C.H.K. participated in the study design and coordination and helped to draft the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

p.bold: Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate

fn.p: This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Dankook University Dental Hospital (IRB No. DKUDHIRB 2025-03-003). The requirement for written informed consent was waived due to the retrospective nature of the study and the use of anonymized patient data.
No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.
